comment.text: Biotin-attachment subunit of the 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase, an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 3-methylcrotonyl-CoA to 3-methylglutaconyl-CoA, a critical step for leucine and isovaleric acid catabolism.
Amino-acid degradation; L-leucine degradation; (S)-3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA from 3-isovaleryl-CoA: step 2/3.
Probably a dodecamer composed of six biotin-containing alpha subunits (MCCC1) and six beta (MCCC2) subunits.

disease.name: 3-methylcrotonoyl-CoA carboxylase 1 deficiency
disease.description: An autosomal recessive disorder of leucine catabolism. The phenotype is variable, ranging from neonatal onset with severe neurological involvement to asymptomatic adults. There is a characteristic organic aciduria with massive excretion of 3-hydroxyisovaleric acid and 3-methylcrotonylglycine, usually in combination with a severe secondary carnitine deficiency.

comment.text: The disease is caused by mutations affecting the gene represented in this entry.

property.value: Defective HLCS causes multiple carboxylase deficiency

feature.description: In MCC1D; clinically asymptomatic form; dbSNP:rs202197951.
In MCC1D; shows no residual activity; dbSNP:rs746500530.
In MCC1D; associated with a reduction of wild-type residual activity; dbSNP:rs201041864.
In MCC1D; unknown pathological significance; dbSNP:rs201386261.
In MCC1D; shows some wild-type residual activity; dbSNP:rs376289130.
